description: From Middle English space, from Anglo-Norman space, variant of espace, espas et al., and spaze, variant of espace, from Latin spatium, from Proto-Indo-European *(s)peh₂- (“to stretch, to pull”).

entries.meaning: (now rare, archaic) Free time; leisure, opportunity. [from 14thc.]
examples: Synonyms: leisure time, spare time

entries.meaning: A specific (specified) period of time. [from 14thc.]
examples: Synonyms: duration, span; see also Thesaurus:period

entries.meaning: An undefined period of time (without qualifier, especially a short period); a while. [from 15thc.]
examples: Synonyms: spell, while; see also Thesaurus:uncertain period

definitionGroups.group: (heading) Unlimited or generalized extent, physical or otherwise.

entries.meaning: Distance between things. [from 14thc.]
examples: Synonyms: break, gap; see also Thesaurus:interspace

entries.meaning: Physical extent across two or three dimensions (sometimes for or to do something). [from 14thc.]
examples: Synonyms: area, volume

entries.meaning: Physical extent in all directions, seen as an attribute of the universe (now usually considered as a part of space-time), or a mathematical model of this. [from 17thc.]
examples: Space is the Phantasme of a Thing existing without the Mind simply.

entries.meaning: The near-vacuum in which planets, stars and other celestial objects are situated; the universe beyond the earth's atmosphere. [from 17thc.]
examples: Synonym: outer space
the first man in space

entries.meaning: The physical and psychological area one needs within which to live or operate; personal freedom. [from 20thc.]
examples: Around the time of my parents' divorce, I learned that reading could also give me space.

definitionGroups.group: (heading) A bounded or specific extent, physical or otherwise.

entries.meaning: A (chiefly empty) area or volume with set limits or boundaries. [from 14thc.]
examples: The street door was open, and we entered a narrow space with washing facilities, curtained off from the courtyard.

entries.meaning: (music) A position on the staff or stave bounded by lines. [from 15thc.]
examples: The note next above Sol is La; La, therefore, stands in the 2nd space; Si, on the 3rd line, &c.

entries.meaning: A gap in text between words, lines etc., or a digital character used to create such a gap. [from 16thc.]
examples: Synonyms: blank, gap, (graphic design) whitespace

entries.meaning: (letterpress typography) A piece of metal type used to separate words, cast lower than other type so as not to take ink, especially one that is narrower than one en (compare quad). [from 17thc.]
examples: Synonyms: quad, quadrat

entries.meaning: A gap; an empty place. [from 17thc.]
examples: Mainstream Hollywood would not cater to the taste for sexual sensation, which left a space for B-movies, including noir.

entries.meaning: (geometry) A set of points, each of which is uniquely specified by a number (the dimensionality) of coordinates.

(countable, mathematics) A generalized construct or set whose members have some property in common; typically there will be a geometric metaphor allowing these members to be viewed as "points". Often used with a restricting modifier describing the members (e.g. vector space), or indicating the inventor of the construct (e.g. Hilbert space). [from 20thc.]
examples: Functional analysis is best approached through a sound knowledge of Hilbert space theory.

entries.meaning: (countable, figuratively) A field, area, or sphere of activity or endeavour.
examples: innovation in the browser space

entries.meaning: Anything analogous to a physical space in which one can interact, such as an online chat room.
examples: Communication in Internet chat spaces allows participants to communicate so freely in the relative safety of anonymity that they forget their privacy.

verbs.description: space (third-person singular simple present spaces, present participle spacing, simple past and past participle spaced)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To roam, walk, wander.
examples: But she as Fayes are wont, in priuie place / Did spend her dayes, and lov'd in forests wyld to space.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To set some distance apart.
examples: Faye had spaced the pots at 8-inch intervals on the windowsill.
The cities are evenly spaced.

entries.meaning: To insert or utilise spaces in a written text.
examples: This paragraph seems badly spaced.

entries.meaning: (transitive, science fiction) To eject into outer space, usually without a space suit.
examples: The captain spaced the traitors.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, science fiction) To travel into and through outer space.
